title: How to master your sense of smell - Alexandra Horowitz

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why humans are not as skilled at smelling as some animals?

options.label: A
options.text: We have fewer olfactory receptors in our noses.

options.label: B
options.text: Our noses are anatomically disadvantaged because we don't put them close enough to the source of the smell.

options.label: C
options.text: We have a weaker sense of smell due to evolution.

options.label: D
options.text: We are not born with the ability to smell.

multiple-choice.question: Where does the actual process of smelling occur in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: In the lungs

options.label: B
options.text: Near the bridge of our noses in the olfactory epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: In the brain's olfactory bulbs

options.label: D
options.text: In the nostrils

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our scent receptors after we take a few sharp sniffs?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more sensitive to new smells.

options.label: B
options.text: They turn off temporarily.

options.label: C
options.text: They start to recognize familiar smells more easily.

options.label: D
options.text: They become overwhelmed and can't detect any smells.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's ability to detect smells decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: Perceiving and imagining odors becomes more automatic.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain's sense of taste is affected.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of dwelling on a smell and trying to describe it, name it, and locate its source?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps to eliminate unpleasant odors.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces our sense of smell.

options.label: C
options.text: It expands our vocabulary of smells.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on our sense of smell.

title: Why do we kiss under mistletoe? - Carlos Reif

title: The Future of Air Travel

options.text: Overcoming the sound barrier

options.label: B
options.text: Generating enough thrust

options.label: C
options.text: Reducing air resistance

options.label: D
options.text: Maintaining stability

multiple-choice.question: What is the Mach number, and how is it used to describe a plane's speed?

options.label: A
options.text: The Mach number is a constant value that represents the speed of sound, and it is used to describe a plane's speed relative to the speed of sound.

options.label: B
options.text: The Mach number is a variable value that represents the speed of sound, and it is used to describe a plane's speed relative to the speed of sound.

options.label: C
options.text: The Mach number is a unit of measurement that represents the speed of a plane, and it is used to describe a plane's speed in absolute terms.

options.label: D
options.text: The Mach number is a ratio of a plane's speed to the speed of sound, and it is used to describe a plane's speed relative to the speed of sound.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The shockwave generated by the plane's engines

options.label: D
options.text: The turbulence created by the plane's wings

options.label: C
options.text: A ramjet engine is used for subsonic flight, while a scramjet engine is used for hypersonic flight.

options.label: D
options.text: A ramjet engine is less efficient than a scramjet engine.

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Why all world maps are wrong

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem that map makers face when trying to represent the surface of a sphere (such as the Earth) as a flat plane?

options.label: A
options.text: The sphere is too large to be represented accurately.

options.label: B
options.text: The sphere is too complex to be represented accurately.

options.label: C
options.text: The surface of a sphere cannot be represented as a plane without some form of distortion.

options.label: D
options.text: The sphere is too small to be represented accurately.

multiple-choice.question: What type of map projection is commonly used for navigation because it preserves direction?

options.label: A
options.text: Gall-Peters projection

options.label: B
options.text: Mercator projection

options.label: C
options.text: Winkel tripel projection

options.label: D
options.text: Cylindrical projection

multiple-choice.question: What is a major criticism of the Mercator projection?

options.label: A
options.text: It distorts the shape of countries.

options.label: B
options.text: It distorts the size of countries, particularly near the poles.

options.label: C
options.text: It is too complex to be used for navigation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too simple to be used for navigation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of the Gall-Peters projection?

options.label: A
options.text: It preserves the shape of countries.

options.label: B
options.text: It preserves the size of countries.

options.label: C
options.text: It is more aesthetically pleasing than other projections.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more complex than other projections.

multiple-choice.question: Why do most web mapping tools, such as Google Maps, still use the Mercator projection?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is the most accurate projection available.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it preserves shape and angles, making close-up views of cities more accurate.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is the simplest projection available.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the most complex projection available.

title: Why doesn’t anything stick to Teflon? - Ashwini Bharathula

multiple-choice.question: What is Teflon, and what is its chemical name?

options.text: Teflon is a brand name for polyethylene, a type of plastic.

options.label: B
options.text: Teflon is a brand name for polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), a synthetic polymer.

options.label: C
options.text: Teflon is a brand name for polypropylene, a type of fiber.

options.label: D
options.text: Teflon is a brand name for polyvinyl chloride (PVC), a type of plastic.

multiple-choice.question: Who discovered Teflon, and in what year?

options.label: A
options.text: Roy Plunkett discovered Teflon in 1928.

options.label: B
options.text: Roy Plunkett discovered Teflon in 1938.

options.label: C
options.text: John Gotti discovered Teflon in 1948.

options.label: D
options.text: DuPont discovered Teflon in 1958.

multiple-choice.question: What makes Teflon non-stick, and what is special about its molecular structure?

options.label: A
options.text: Teflon is non-stick because of its high coefficient of friction, and its molecular structure is made of short chains of atoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Teflon is non-stick because of its low coefficient of friction, and its molecular structure is made of long chains of atoms with fluorine atoms surrounding the carbon backbone.

options.label: C
options.text: Teflon is non-stick because of its chemical reactivity, and its molecular structure is made of branched chains of atoms.

options.label: D
options.text: Teflon is non-stick because of its high surface energy, and its molecular structure is made of cyclic chains of atoms.

multiple-choice.question: How is Teflon attached to a pan, and what is the purpose of the primer?

options.label: A
options.text: Teflon is attached to a pan using a strong adhesive, and the primer is used to roughen the surface of the pan.

options.label: B
options.text: Teflon is attached to a pan using a special primer, and the primer acts like glue to help the Teflon stick to the pan.

options.label: C
options.text: Teflon is attached to a pan using heat and pressure, and the primer is used to reduce the surface energy of the pan.

options.label: D
options.text: Teflon is attached to a pan using a chemical reaction, and the primer is used to catalyze the reaction.

multiple-choice.question: Is it safe to cook in a Teflon-coated pan, and what are the potential health risks associated with Teflon?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not safe to cook in a Teflon-coated pan because Teflon can release toxic fumes at high temperatures.

options.label: B
options.text: It is safe to cook in a Teflon-coated pan as long as it is not heated above 500°F, but there are potential health risks associated with the manufacture of Teflon.

options.label: C
options.text: It is safe to cook in a Teflon-coated pan, but there are potential health risks associated with consuming Teflon that has flaked off a scratched pan.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not safe to cook in a Teflon-coated pan because Teflon can react with food and cause health problems.

title: The neuroscience of imagination - Andrey Vyshedskiy

multiple-choice.question: According to the Mental Synthesis Theory, what is the key to perceiving two separate objects as a single image in our imagination?

options.label: A
options.text: The neuronal ensembles for the objects are activated at different times.

options.label: B
options.text: The neuronal ensembles for the objects are activated at the same time.

options.label: C
options.text: The neuronal ensembles for the objects are not activated at all.

options.label: D
options.text: The prefrontal cortex is not involved in the process.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Hebbian principle in neuroscience?

options.label: A
options.text: Neurons that fire together wire together.

options.label: B
options.text: Neurons that fire separately wire together.

options.label: C
options.text: Neurons that fire together wire separately.

options.label: D
options.text: Neurons that fire separately wire separately.

options.label: A
options.text: To activate neuronal ensembles in the posterior cortex at different times.

options.label: B
options.text: To activate neuronal ensembles in the posterior cortex at the same time.

options.label: C
options.text: To deactivate neuronal ensembles in the posterior cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: To create new neuronal ensembles in the posterior cortex.

options.label: B
options.text: To speed up electrical signals.

options.label: C
options.text: To block electrical signals.

options.label: D
